column1: 28-year-old chef found dead in San Francisco mall
A 28-year-old chef who recently moved to San Francisco was found dead in the stairwell of a local mall.
The victim's brother testified that he could not imagine anyone wanting to harm him, saying, "He finally got back on his feet."
The body found Wednesday morning at the Westfield Mall was identified as 28-year-old Frank Galicia of San Francisco, the San Francisco Department of Forensic Medicine said.
The San Francisco Police Department said the death was being treated as homicide and an investigation is ongoing.

The victim's brother, Louis Galicia, told San Francisco station KGO that Frank, who used to work as a chef in Boston, got his dream job as a chef at the Sons & Daughters restaurant in San Francisco six months ago.
A spokesman for the Sons & Daughters said they were "shocked and devastated" by his death.
We are a small team that works like a close family and we will miss him dearly, the spokesman added.
Our thoughts and condolences are with Frank's family and friends at this difficult time.
Louis Galicia said that Frank initially lived in hostels, but that "things finally went up for him."
'He found an apartment, he had a girlfriend, 'Louis Garcia told KGO.
Louis Galicia said he could not imagine anyone wanting to harm his younger brother.
He was a kind person with a big heart.
His way of connecting with his family was to always cook us something, prepare us dinner, "Louis Galicia said.
He never wanted to be involved in any kind of altercation.
He was the brother who swam with the stream.
With everything that goes wrong in the world, he was this uncut diamond that shone brightly every day, he said.
Anyone with information on the case is asked to call the SFPD's tip line at 415-575-4444.
Jennifer Aniston: I'm always pigeonholed
Jennifer Aniston doesn't always have to be perfect or successful.
The Hollywood star has now made that abundantly clear in an interview.
'I'm always pigeonholed or labelled from the outside, which usually have little to do with me and reality. '
'I don't want to be perfect and successful all the time. '
'To be honest, I don't really care about those things. '
Jennifer Aniston, 47, can only laugh at being called "Miss Perfect," as she explains in the latest issue of Cosmopolitan.
The actress prefers to spend her time at home, in front of the TV with a loose bun and Mexican food, the magazine said.
She added: 'We women don't have to be married or have children to be perfect,' the Hollywood star said.
In her new film, "Mother's Day," Aniston stars as a single mother of two sons.
The film will be released on August 25.
Golfer Langer receives the Sports Pyramid
His experience on the horse is manageable.
At the end of a golf tournament in South Africa Bernhard Langer was looking for some variety with a ride on the beach.
It was a first for the 58-year-old.
CHIO: "Golden sports pyramid" for Bernhard Langer
After a few minutes the horses remembered their end of the day, they galloped home to the feeding troughs.
One kilometer at this speed, I was scared.
It wasn't a good experience, Langer said.
And with that the riding career ended again.
On Saturday, Germany's best golfer of all time - 101 tournament wins - was back near horses.
He and his family were led around the grounds of the ALRV, he did not even swing on a horse for photo purposes.
Langer was in Aachen for the first time and thus also at the CHIO.
The reason was quite convincing.
The German Sports Aid presented the man from Anhausen with the Golden Sports Pyramid at a small gala.
The personable sportsman has no shortage of awards.
Federal Cross of Merit, Silver Laurel Leaf, Champions Tour Player of the Year...
Even the British Queen has ennobled him.
Langer is the 18th winner of the sports pyramid.
On Saturday he met the first prize winner Hans Günter Winkler in Aachen.
This award means a lot to me, says Langer, "because it is awarded not only for sporting success, but also for social commitment."
Langer has been promoting young talent for decades.
And so he immediately passed on the prize money of 25,000 euros.
The two-time US Masters winner was inducted into the "Hall of Fame of German Sports" on Saturday along with 15 other outstanding athletes.

Among the winners are the athletes Hartwig Gauder and Harald Schmitt, the gymnast Eberhard Gienger, the fencers Cornelia Hanisch, Alexander Pusch and Arnd Schmitt, the rower Peter-Michael Kolbe, bobsleigh rider Meinhard Nehmer, the judoka Frank Wieneke, the show jumper Alwin Schockemöhle and posthumously the handball player Erhard Wunderlich.
Many of these sporting legends came to Aachen on Saturday.
After the official part, the illustrious company went to the jumping stadium, where the Lavazza Prize was presented.
Bernhard Langer kept his distance from the big beasts.
Clintons and Trump's Economic Policy Comparison: It's All About the Money
Investing in infrastructure and blocking the TTP trade deal is what both Clinton and Trump want.
However, the two US presidential candidates disagree on tax and energy policy, as well as on a matter of principle.
Underlying the differences in economic policy between Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton is a fundamental, rather philosophical difference.
The, about the role of the state.
Trump wants to keep them small, warning of how government can hurt the economy - with taxes and regulations.
Clinton wants to tax the economy to death and regulate it to death, he says.
He himself, however, would be very different, Trump claims.
He will massively scale back regulations, and he is pushing for far-reaching tax reform with lower tax rates - for individuals and businesses.
Clinton, on the other hand, says the state has certain tasks to perform, it has opportunities for the disadvantaged, and it needs money to do so.
That's why taxes would be raised on the rich, she says.
Interestingly, the two are very close on infrastructure.
Trump and Clinton say almost word for word on the need to invest.
The Democratic candidate even announces the biggest investment in new jobs since World War II.
Government infrastructure investment programs are classic Democratic policies and are strongly opposed by, say, the anti-government tea party wing of the Republican Party.
So Trump could still face intra-party discussions.
The differences in energy and climate policy are clearer.
Trump wants to build coal-fired power plants and ramp up coal production in the US.
Oil production should also be possible in previously protected areas, and he wants to withdraw from the Paris climate agreement.
Clinton, on the other hand, explicitly wants to expand renewable energy with her investment program, saying, "A country will become a clean-energy superpower and create millions of jobs."
'It's going to be either China, Germany or America - I want us to be. '
But it's not just infrastructure - the two rivals are not too far apart on international trade agreements, either.
TPP, the Trans-Pacific Trade Agreement, neither wants to sign.
At the same time, both do not want to isolate the US from international trade - they just want to better protect American jobs.
They should be better paid, Clinton says.
The current minimum wage of $7.25 is a pittance.
She wants to raise it to $15 an hour.
What Trump wants to do on this issue is not entirely clear: once he says the minimum wage must go up, then he says it must not be changed.
But the big discussion in the coming months is likely to revolve more around the tax policies of the two camps.
On one side is Trump, who wants to ease the burden on the economy and citizens to boost growth.
His critics accuse him of only widening the budget deficit.
On the other side is Clinton, who wants to at least require the rich to pay more taxes, and whose critics say that more taxes are not the solution.
Escape: "Every refugee woman has experience of sexual violence"
Sexual violence is almost an everyday occurrence for women fleeing alone.
When they arrive in Germany, they are often traumatised.
A house offers refuge.
Four women sit in a large kitchen.
Each has a baby with them, who is not more than one year old.
One held her young son in her arms.
He looks curiously into the room with wide eyes.
His mother stares at the tabletop.
Until she realises she's being watched.
She smiles briefly and kisses the little one.
The scene seems normal.
Until you talk to Katrin Bahr.
She is the managing director of Condrobs, a provider of social assistance services in Bavaria, and deals, among other things, with the subject of women on the run.
The four women in the kitchen are refugees.
They live in the north of Munich in one of the few decentralised shelters for single women and their children in Bavaria.
In January, Condrobs opened the facility together with Pro Familia and the Munich Women's Aid.
It was recently officially opened.
There are 60 people living there - about 40 women and 20 children.
There are no men - not even as visitors.
The exception is a security guard at the door.
It is not an exaggeration to say that every woman who arrives here has experienced sexual violence while on the run, says Bahr.
Men flee because of wars, because they are politically persecuted, because they are threatened with torture or death, or because their families send them to Europe as bearers of hope, she says.
For women, other reasons for fleeing predominate: "Many steal away secretly because they see no other way out."
In their homeland, they have experienced sexual violence, forced marriages, honour killings, slavery or forced prostitution.
That drives them on.
On the run, it continues.
It is not uncommon for smugglers to demand a sexual act for a bottle of water, for example, says Bahr.
And the women are alone, they are not protected by their families.
Those who believe that the end will come as soon as they arrive in Germany are mistaken, says Bahr.
Here too, single women in refugee shelters are often regarded as inferior and, at worst, abused.
As a result, about 90 percent of the women who live in the accommodation in the north of Munich are traumatized, she estimates.
'Some of the children certainly weren't born voluntarily. '
Many women are so used to not saying anything.
'Or they don't dare speak openly about what they've experienced because the shame is too great. '
Since they often do not know how to help themselves, more accommodation is needed just for them, Bahr demands.
In Bavaria, the seven district governments are responsible for housing refugees.
When asked whether they were aware of a project similar to the one in Munich in their area of responsibility, some answered no.
In the Upper Palatinate and Upper Franconia, for example, there is no such thing in government accommodation.
Even in Swabia, women who have fled alone are not accommodated separately, says Karl-Heinz Meyer, spokesman for the government.
In Upper Bavaria, Lower Franconia and Middle Franconia, in some shared accommodation there are floors or own houses only for single women and their children.
The exception is Lower Bavaria, where there are two central accommodations exclusively for women.
The Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality in the European Parliament also calls for women to be housed separately from men.
A study published for the committee said: 'It is very important that men and women are housed separately.'
If there is a lack of privacy or if men and women are accommodated together, violence against women can occur - on an ongoing basis.
Above all, the washrooms should be separate and easily accessible for women, the study says.
The extent to which the women feel this need for protection can be seen from the crush on the house in Munich.
We've had a long waiting list since word got around that we were there, Bahr says.
You could easily open a second house.
Junior doctors strike: Calls for new industrial action
Assistant doctors' representatives have called on their union to approve new industrial action in their dispute over a new contract.
The Junior Doctors Committee (JDC) of the British Medical Association (BMA) has called on its entire council to approve more industrial action from early September.
The JDC said ministers had failed to address concerns about the contract.
Junior doctors and medical students voted in July to reject a contract agreed with the BMA.
It was rejected by 58% of its members who voted in the elections.
In a letter to members posted on Twitter on Thursday night, JDC chairwoman Ellen McCourt said the government had remained "stubbornly quiet" on issues that led to the contract being rejected.
She said: 'In light of this, the JDC board has voted to reject the proposed new contract in its entirety and has requested formal renegotiation of all your concerns.'

In response to the government's silence, the JDC board today made a formal request for a special meeting of the BMA council to approve an ongoing programme of escalating industrial action starting in early September.
The disputes led to junior doctors striking six times this year, the first total stoppages in NHS history.
The head of the BMA's junior doctors, Dr Johann Malawana, resigned after the vote to reject the agreed contract terms recommended by the BMA.
He told BMA members during meetings held before the vote by 54,000 junior doctors and medical students that the contract was advantageous and should be adopted.
After the vote, Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt said the contract would be compulsory for doctors in England.
Russia and Turkey: An "alliance of outsiders"?
It was a gesture that ended a crisis.
The leaders of Russia and Turkey met Tuesday to shake hands and announce an official end to an eight-month war of words and economic sanctions.
But when Vladimir Putin receives his Turkish counterpart in the gilded hall of the St. Petersburg Palace, I cannot help feeling that Ankara most wants this reconciliation.
There was the handshake, yes.
But Putin's smile seemed narrow-lipped, and he exuded little warmth, even by his low-key standards.
Recep Tayyip Erdogan, on the other hand, repeatedly referred to his "dear friend" Putin - five times, according to one report.
I couldn't count it anymore.
He also promised that relations with Russia would not only return to their pre-crisis levels, but would even improve.
The next day, a newspaper described Erdogan as behaving as if nothing bad had ever happened.
To me, his enthusiasm seemed to suggest the opposite.
But a sustained coolness radiated by Putin showed that the Russian leader had forgotten nothing.
Rather, the cause of the crisis was the first thing he mentioned in his introductory remarks: Turkey's shooting down of a Russian warplane on the Syrian border.
Moscow's reaction at the time was furious.
Putin issued a statement accusing Ankara of stabbing Russia in the back.
The offence was even greater as it was committed by an alleged friend.
Rebuilding trust will be difficult, if not impossible.
Public opinion in Russia has changed since November.
For months, the state-controlled media carried out a ferocious, unrestrained attack on Ankara.
Suddenly, it seemed that the Turks were to blame for everything.
Most serious were allegations by senior officials that Erdogan's own family had benefited from illegal oil trading in areas of Syria controlled by the so-called Islamic State.
He has vehemently denied this.
But in St. Petersburg, the official message was that it was time to look ahead.
After all, that meeting took place only because Putin received the apology he wanted to hear from President Erdogan.
Russia had some sort of victory.
For Ankara, the benefits of a ceasefire are clear.
Erdogan needs all the friends he can get, first and foremost, after he was nearly impeached in a failed coup last month.
Repeated terrorist attacks on Turkey have also shaken him.
But there are also economic motives.
Russian sanctions have hit Turkey hard - particularly the ban on charter flights, which typically bring several million Russian tourists to the Turkish coast each year.
The number has fallen by almost 90%.
In Russia, tour operators and charter companies will be relieved when flights resume.
They are counting on a late-season rush to the Mediterranean.
This week, state television predicted cheaper fruit and vegetables once Turkish agricultural imports are allowed again.
As one report in Vedemosti put it: "Tourists long there, tomatoes long here."
But the visit had added political value for Moscow.
Ankara is angry with the West, seeing its response to the attempted takeover as a weak response.
Add to that lingering resentment about the snail's pace of EU accession negotiations, and Putin - eager to capitalize on the cool mood and reduce Turkey's relationship with the West.
The Russian leader certainly won a bonus in Ankara for calling for support for the elected authorities after the attempted coup.
This is a matter of course for Moscow, which itself has a deep-seated fear of regime change.

The summit in this splendid seaside palace enabled Russia and Turkey to portray what one analyst once described to me as an "alliance of outsiders": two countries that feel rejected and mistreated by the West and are now allied.
Yet, despite the public reconciliation, there are still major differences between the two.
The biggest difference is Syria, where Moscow recently assumed the role of peacemaker, but where Russia and Turkey support opposing sides.
It could be telling that after nearly three hours of initial talks, both presidents testified at the news conference that they had not even touched on the issue.
Turkey's president deliberately avoided answering a question about their differences, while Putin chose to emphasize them.
There is no clear consensus on where a common denominator on Syria can be found.

But after months of open hostilities - and given the potential for total disaster when NATO member Turkey shot down the Russian fighter jet - it is surely better that the two leaders at least talk to each other again.
Royal Bank of Scotland no longer available to customers outside Scotland
The RBS brand is to be reduced to a back-office role, according to the bank's chief executive.
Royal Bank of Scotland will no longer be available to customers outside Scotland.
Ross McEwan told BBC Scotland that the RBS brand was linked to the bank's global ambitions.
The bank has distanced itself since it nearly collapsed and had to be bailed out eight years ago.
During this time, brand strategists have used RBS to protect other consumer financial brands.
She has backed international sport with millions of pounds in sponsorship, from Six Nations rugby to Wimbledon winner Andy Murray.
But now she has decided to focus on more national brands.
Royal Bank of Scotland will only be available to customers in Scotland, but will not be initialised.
In England and Wales, all RSB references, devolved headquarters and listing will move to NatWest.
The Ulster Bank brand is already used by customers in the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland.
There are other smaller retail brands that will gain more prominence - Coutts, Adam & Co, Drummond and Holt's Military Bank.
McEwan was interviewed by customers and staff in Inverness-shire during a sightseeing tour.
He told BBC Scotland: "The RSB brand will become our investor brand and the brand under which our staff will be employed as we become more of a bank of brands."
When the bank itself became a global brand, RBS became a global brand.
I am now saying that we are not pursuing global objectives, but local objectives.
Each of these brands will stand for something completely different in their own communities, and our employees will work with customers under these brands.
RBS has already said it will no longer continue its Six Nations sponsorship and that it will increase the visibility of the various brands in its sports sponsorship.
It's time for us to become the Bank of Brands, because how do we focus internally (we asked) on making this a better bank for customers? the chief executive said.
It would have been very cynical three years ago if we had said we would be a great bank for our customers and launched these brands.
But with our work, the focus on customer needs and not our own, I think you will see a lot of change.
We can re-launch these brands, so I think the time has come.
Frankie Dettori claims his 3,000th win at Newmarket on Predilection
Dettori sprays champagne after a double at Newmarket that earned him 3,000th win
Jockey Frankie Dettori secured his 3,000th British win at Newmarket on Friday.
He set a milestone on Predilection, which is trained by John Gosden, at his local track with his second win of the night.
The 45-year-old Italian is the sixth jockey to reach the milestone in flat racing.
He follows Sir Gordon Richards, Doug Smith, Lester Piggott, Pat Eddry and Willie Carson.
Three-time winner Dettori, who previously won on Ghayyar, said: 'It's special.'
I'm very emotional because my family is here too
I'm very happy it happened at Newmarket because I landed here 30 years ago.
It's not a big meeting, it's not Royal Ascot - it's a banal Friday night with 20,000 people.
I am relieved and very humbled.
Dettori takes the cheer as he takes victory on Predilection
Two jockeys have reached the milestone in steeplechasing - jockey Richard Johnson and retired 20-time winner Sir Anthony McCoy, who racked up more than 4,300 wins in a record-breaking career.
Lester Piggott, the nine-time Derby winner, had 4,493 career wins
Frankie is one of the best jockeys of the modern era and it is no surprise he has reached this milestone that few have reached before him.
He has style and is strong but it is his tactical intellect that sets him apart from the others in the weight room.
He is a fantastic ambassador for racing and his enthusiasm and charisma has been inspiring fans for years.
I told Frankie at Epsom a few weeks ago that if he wasn't just a weekend and big-race jockey, he would have won 6,000 already!
Frankie has ridden winners in the UK for almost 30 years, which is great.
He has a lively personality, which is good for a British race, but beyond that he is an incredible jockey.
Frankie Dettori celebrated the milestone with a typical Flying Dismount
From Flying Finishes to Flying Dismounts, Frankie Dettori has been the figurehead of British Flat racing for two decades.
It was nerve-wracking.
A string of major tournament wins, including his famous "Glorious Seven" at Ascot in 1996, but he also survived a plane crash and was banned for drugs.
Three years ago he initially struggled when returning from his six-month suspension, but he showed impressive strength of character to defy his doubters and return to his best form.
And he is far from finished - Dettori has previously said he wants to continue competing until he is at least 50.
Russia's Putin fires chief of staff Sergei Ivanov
Russian President Vladimir Putin has unexpectedly fired his chief of staff Sergei Ivanov.
Ivanov was part of Putin's inner circle of trust for many years.
The 63-year-old has been appointed Special Representative for Environment and Transport Affairs.
A Kremlin statement said Putin had "ordered Ivanov's dismissal from his duties as chairman of Russia's presidential administration," without giving reasons.
Anton Vaino, who had been Ivanov's deputy since 2012, was appointed as his successor.
Vaino, 44, is a former diplomat.
Born in 1972 in the Estonian capital Tallinn, he graduated from the prestigious Moscow State Institute of International Relations (MGIMO) and worked in the Embassy in Tokyo.
The Kremlin's website says (in Russian) that he was later chief of protocol and chief of staff to government staff.
Of his appointment, he told Putin: 'Thank you for your trust.'
I believe that the most important task of the government is to support your work as Head of State in drafting laws and monitoring the implementation of your instructions.
Putin told the Russian TV channel on Friday that Ivanov had asked to leave his post and recommended Vaino as his successor.
Are the smiling faces convincing?
The move has shrouded Moscow in secrecy.
Sergei Ivanov has long been one of Vladimir Putin's closest confidants and, like him, works for the Soviet secret service, the KGB.
As chief of staff, he was one of the most powerful men in the country.
In a televised meeting with President Putin, both men claimed that the chief of staff was resigning at his own request.
But despite smiling for the cameras, few here are convinced - especially now, just before the general election.
So is this the result of some kind of power struggle?
Nobody knows at the moment.
But the official claim - that a man once touted as a potential president suddenly wants to lead Russia's environmental policy - was met with deep skepticism.

In his remarks to Putin, quoted on the Kremlin's website, Ivanov said, "It is true that in early 2012, in a conversation, I asked you to entrust me with this very complicated - one might almost say arduous - post for four years.
As it turns out, I have been chairman of the Russian presidential administration for four years and eight months.
Ivanov took up the post in December 2011.
He was previously deputy prime minister and defence minister.
He is a member of the Russian Security Council and, like Putin, a former member of the KGB state security service.
In the late 1990 "s, when Putin was chairman of the Federal Security Service (FSB), which replaced the KGB, Ivanov was appointed his deputy.
When Putin came to power, he named Ivanov as one of the five people he trusted most.
It was once thought that Ivanov could become president of Russia after Putin's second term, because a third term would have violated the constitution.
But that post was taken by another close Putin ally, Dmitry Medvedev.
Putin became prime minister before being re-elected president three and a half years later.
Criminal Minds star Thomas Gibson fired after slamming producers
Gibson was involved in a physical altercation on the set of the series in Los Angeles last month.
ABC Studios and CBS Television Studios, which produce the series, announced his termination in a joint statement.
Gibson, who played special agent Aaron Hotchner, publicly apologized on Thursday before announcing his termination.
There were artistic differences and disagreements on set.
I regret the incident, 'he said in a statement.

Details of how Gibson's character will be written out of the show, which follows a team of FBI agents, are expected to be released at a later date, according to the statement from ABC Studios and CBS Television Studios.
The 54-year-old, who previously starred in the sitcom Dharma & Greg, has been with the show since its first season in 2005.
I love Criminal Minds and have put all my heart and soul into it for the last 12 years, Gibson said in a statement released Friday.
I had hoped to be there until the end, but that will not be possible now.
I would just like to thank the writers, producers, actors, our wonderful crew and most of all the best fans you could wish for a show.
The twelfth season is scheduled to air on September 28.
Mystery over fish that ended up in garden in Banff
A Banff resident called for help identifying the fish that turned up in his garden in Banff.
Kevin Bain thinks the 75 fish could be sand eels spewed from a fountain.
Mr Bain, who lives about 500 metres from the sea, posted a video of the spectacle on Periscope in the hope that someone might shed some light on the appearance of the two-inch-long fish.
Queensferry Crossing: Bridge now linked to Fife
The £1.35bn project is due to be completed by May 2017
Engineers have connected the north deck of the Queensferry Crossing to the viaduct - meaning the bridge is now connected to Fife.
It is the first of four closures of the "deck blowers," which are nearing completion around each of the bridge's three towers.
The Fife bridge section is now 600 metres long and weighs 30,000 tonnes.
It has 10,000 tonnes of steel and 20,000 tonnes of concrete, as well as 46 cables.
The £1.35bn project is due to be completed by May 2017.
Economy Minister Keith Brown paid a visit to the site today and was one of the first to walk from the land to the bridge.
He said: "This is a historic and symbolic moment in the construction of the Queensferry Crossing.
We are all witnessing an engineering feat of truly epic proportions on this project with over 30,000 tonnes of concrete and steel used for this part of the bridge alone.
Despite the massive size and weight of the bridge, the completion of the closure between the viaduct and the bridge deck is a delicate activity that requires extremely precise tolerances for fit.

In total, almost 79% of the entire bridge decks are in place and the last section of the deck is now being cast in concrete for the deck at Rosyth, meaning that the entire deck is ready to be lifted into place on the bridge.
Michael Martin, Forth Crossing Bridge Constructors project manager, said: "The first closure is a significant milestone in any bridge project.
In this fantastic project, the closure represents pioneering construction and civil engineering.
After the installation of the last section of the road deck and its connection to the north tower deck, which is under construction, we then had to close the remaining gap on the north or land side.
This was achieved by pulling the northern feeder bridge 700 millimetres south.
This was a massive and at the same time very delicate activity.
Massive, as the viaduct is 222 metres long, weighs about 6,000 tonnes and had to be pulled upwards at an incline of about 3%.
It was tricky because the tolerances the team was working towards were tiny - they were only a few millimetres on each side.
Fortunately, everything went very well.
Moelfre Bay rescue: Three men "lucky to be alive"
Three men are "lucky to be alive" after being thrown from their fishing boat off Anglesey.
The Moelfre RNLI lifeboat station raised the alarm at 13: 20 BST on Friday after a crew observed the incident at Moelfre Bay.
The three men had difficulty swimming to safety as their boat continued to move on its own.
We saw the boat turn around near them and imagined the worst, said Moelfre Rescue Station Chief Vince Jones.
Fortunately, the strong winds had already blown the boat out of reach by the time we got to the water, he added.
Two of the men were rescued by a local fishing boat, while the third man, aged in his 60s, was found exhausted and hanging from a buoy without a life jacket.
They all got on board the lifeboat and were taken back to the rescue station
Mr Jones said: 'The three men who were thrown into the water are lucky to be uninjured and still alive.
The boat engine had an emergency stop line, but when the boat capsized, it detached from the person who was steering the boat.
Someone was watching over these men today.
Seriously injured man stabs his ex-girlfriend
A man attacked his ex-girlfriend with a knife in Hamburg-Harburg and seriously injured her.
Police said yesterday that the 50-year-old had been given the keys to the flat to retrieve his personal belongings.
Instead, the alcoholic offender cut up his ex-girlfriend's clothes.
When she came to the flat, he stabbed her twice.
The 44-year-old suffered injuries to her hand and body.
Police were able to arrest the offender.
While destroying his ex-girlfriend's clothes, the 50-year-old called his mother.
She then alerted his sister.
Together with her partner, the 45-year-old wanted to reassure her brother.
But she could not persuade him to leave the apartment.
So she left the house with her partner.
They met the man's ex-partner in the street.
When the two women entered the apartment again, the 50-year-old pushed his sister aside and attacked his ex-girlfriend.
Who builds affordable housing?
The SPD and the Greens believe that investors should be held much more accountable in future.
How to react to the bad news that Brunswick will lose nearly 1300 affordable homes in the next few years?
The SPD is proposing a "housing action plan" for the next council meeting.
But controversy is inevitable.
First and foremost, the question is: who is actually going to build the affordable housing?
There is no regulation so far.

SPD parliamentary group chairman Christoph Bratmann says: "We agree with the Greens that anyone who wants to build on urban land will have to designate 20 percent of all apartments as social housing in the future."
However, the cheap apartments can also be built in existing buildings.
But the big point of contention at City Hall, Bratmann said, is: "How do you deal with investors who want to build on private land?"
We want investors to build at least 10 per cent, but preferably 20 per cent, of social housing on such sites.
A new urban housing incentive program, which will cost millions and has yet to be financed, is intended to provide incentives.
The problem, Bratmann said, is that "there is no agreement between the groups at the moment."
The CDU wants to make as few regulations as possible for investors.
The left wants even tougher restrictions on investors.
Nonetheless, Bratmann said, the situation in the housing market is worsening.
If the action plan is implemented, this will provide for additional tasks in the construction administration.
More staff are needed.
It is unclear whether we will get the skilled workers.
But the program is not yet complete: the roughly 1260 new apartments that were supposed to be built anyway.
But how do you compensate for the loss of another 1,300 affordable homes, whose subsidies will expire in the next few years?
By 2020 alone, there will be 500 homes.
Planning spokeswoman Nicole Palm said expiring bonds should now be purchased by the city to prevent that from happening.
Consideration should also be given to bringing homes back into price fixing.
This is possible in the western city.
The problem could be solved in one fell swoop.
In the western city, deadlines expire at the end of the year.
Around 1800 apartments could be brought back into the price fixing for low-cost apartments.
But that is not what the owners, the housing associations, want.
If the number of social housing units in the western city is increased drastically again, one moves away from the goal of so-called mixing.
There should no longer be a concentration of socially disadvantaged people in just a few districts.
The Greens expect that there will still be movement in the discussion.

Amid the frenzy of the Olympics, the Zen of the trampoline
Wherever you are, however late it is, it is the Olympics.
The events in Rio de Janeiro feel constant and inevitable, a frantic relay race between competition and aspiration.
It is as if the Olympic torch itself were a burning stick, passed from crossbowman to swimmer to gymnast to triathlete.

You can't turn on the TV, read a newspaper, or listen to your neighbor's conversation in the coffee shop queue without hearing about Simone Biles, Katie Ledecky, or the Michael Phelps vs. Chad le Clos fight.
And then there's Logan Dooley.

Dooley, attending the Olympics for the first time and a swarm of women with dimples, could well have been among those household names being broadcast in prime time, built up by sponsors and feel-good TV commercials, if he were a swimmer, gymnast or even fencer.

The Olympic flame does not illuminate every event in the same way.
Further from the centre, partly in the shade, there are sports that are not generally recognised: air pistol shooting, archery, badminton, taekwondo.
We will always have the breaststroke and long may it reign.
But if I may modestly make the case for my particular favourite, let me draw attention to the discreet charm of the trampoline.

Although trampoline jumping has been an Olympic event since 2000, when it made its debut in Sydney, it has been so sparsely attended for the last 16 years that many of those I interviewed did not know it was an Olympic sport at all.
It could also be regional ignorance.
Although the United States sent athletes to compete, it has never won a medal in trampoline jumping and until 2012 had an athlete who made it to the final round.
The Chinese and the Russians tend to share the prizes for the men and the Chinese and the Canadians for the women.
Dong Dong of China and Rosie MacLennan of Canada will defend their gold medals from London this year.
Trampoline jumping has a certain outsider charm, partly because, to the unenlightened ear, it sounds more appropriate for a clown school than for the Olympics.
At this point, I should admit that I am not an expert, but only an earthbound enthusiast.
It has humorous potential - the cartoonish tremor of its never-ending impact - but also the grace of gymnastics and diving, the two sports it essentially unites.
The word "trampoline" comes from the Spanish El Trampoline, which means "springboard."
Aspiring winners jump on a giant trampoline, shoot almost 30 feet into the air and have to perform a series of falling movements (twists, pike and somersaults) before landing on their feet.
According to the official Olympic program, they are evaluated according to execution, difficulty and "flight time."
Thirty-two athletes from 17 countries, 16 men and 16 women, will compete in Rio.

Medal hopefuls need to go further, faster, up and over in their pursuit of gold, sometimes to the finish, sometimes back and forth, up and down the playground.
They chase not only the finish line or the exit wall, but also another mocking target on television: the world or the Olympic record.
The purposeful pursuit is noble, admirable, even fanatical - and it is enough to move even a spectator to tears.
But it's also what I find a little tiring, even watching these games.
The trampoline offers a reprieve.
The vector of the trampoline jumper is above.
Moving forward is not the goal.
He or she bounces off, seemingly weightless like an astronaut, goes up, then down, then up again effortlessly.

Here, too, there is competition, not without difficulty, of course, but during the exercise there is no frantic attack on the target, no vaulting into the distance, only the dreamy, elegant suspension of time and gravity.
It's as Zen as competing in the Olympics can be.

NBC will air the finals as part of an afternoon block on both days starting at 2 p.m.
Amid the Olympic mania, they promise a quiet, nice moment, one that is likely to be overlooked in the general tumult.

If raising awareness can only be achieved by gasping and objectifying male athletes - as the male US gymnasts recently suggested, according to The Wall Street Journal - then Mr Dooley expects his new fan base to be gasping for air.
A Generation Protests in Ethiopia, Long a U.S. Ally
Violent protests in Ethiopia
Demonstrators demanding political change in Ethiopia have met with violent opposition from the government.
Witnesses say dozens of protesters were killed in exchanges of gunfire during clashes with police.
Is Ethiopia about to collapse?
For the past decade, it has been one of Africa's most stable countries, a solid ally of the West with a fast-growing economy.
But in recent months, anti-government protests have rocked the country and spread to more and more areas.
Last week, thousands of people took to the streets demanding fundamental political change.
The government's response has been ruthless, according to human rights groups.
Witnesses said police shot and killed dozens of unarmed protesters.
Videos circulating of the protests, believed to be from last year or early this year, show security guards beating young people with sticks as they were forced to do a handstand against a wall.
The head of the UN human rights agency is now calling for a thorough investigation.

After Nigeria, Ethiopia is the most populous country in Africa and its stability is valued by the West.

American military and intelligence agencies are working closely with the Ethiopians to combat terrorist threats beyond the region, particularly in Somalia. Few countries in Africa, if any, receive so much Western aid.
Ethiopia's economy expanded at a remarkable pace.
Its infrastructure has improved dramatically - there is a new commuter train in the capital, Addis Ababa.
The streets are usually quiet, safe and clean.

While Ethiopia has been anything but a model of democracy - human rights organizations have consistently cited government repression - the country's opposition has been curtailed, effectively silencing dissidents.
Many were sent into exile or prison, killed or driven into the vastness of the desert.
But that could change.
If you oppress people and they have no other options but to protest, it breaks out, said Seyoum Teshome, a lecturer in central Ethiopia.
All the youth are protesting.
A generation protests.
There are numerous complaints covering everything from land use to the stranglehold on power of the ruling coalition.
After a widely criticized election last year, the ruling party and its allies won the opposition's last seat and now control 100 percent of parliament.
At the same time, tensions are rising along the border with Eritrea; a battle over the jagged, disputed line claimed hundreds of lives in June.

Analysts fear that separatists such as the Oromo Liberation Front or the Ogaden National Liberation Front, which have been more or less defeated in recent years, could take advantage of the turmoil and rearm.
Several factors explain why, after years of simmering beneath the surface, feelings of bitterness are now exploding.
The first seems innocuous: smartphones.
Only in recent years have many Ethiopians been able to communicate through social media, as cheaper smartphones became more common and Internet services improved.

Even if the government blocks access to Facebook and Twitter, which it does periodically, especially during protests, many people can still communicate through Internet proxies that hide where they are.
Several young Ethiopians said they gathered for protests.
The second factor is that there is more solidarity between the Oromos and Amharas, the two largest ethnic groups in Ethiopia.
The Oromos and Amharas are not natural enemies.
For eons, the Amharas, who hail from Ethopia's predominantly Christian highlands, prospered in politics and economics while exploiting the Oromos, many of whom are Muslim and live in lowland areas.
But that, too, is changing.
We are coordinating under one umbrella, said Mulatu Gemechu, a leader of the Oromos.
The largest protests took place in areas of the Amhara and Oromos.

Many Amharas and Oromos feel that Ethiopia is unfairly dominated by members of the Tigray ethnic group, which makes up about 6% of the population and dominates the military, intelligence, commerce, and politics.
The third reason for the unrest is the death of Meles Zenawi.
Mr Meles, a former rebel leader, was Ethiopia's prime minister for 17 years until his death from an undisclosed illness in 2012.
He was regarded as a tactical genius, a man who could think around corners.
Analysts say he was particularly adept at spotting early signs of discontent and using special envoys to edit opponents and neutralize them.
The current regime lacks that basic skill, said Mr. Abdi, a conflict analyst.
Ethiopia's new prime minister, Hailemariam Desalegn, was chosen for relatively obscure reasons to replace Mr Meles.
Unlike Mr Meles, who came from the Tigray region of northern Ethiopia, Mr Hailemariam comes from the south.
Analysts say he does not enjoy the trust of the Tigray-controlled security services.
Many fear the result will be more bloodshed.
The last time Ethiopia experienced such turmoil was in 2005, when thousands protested against elections that analysts said appeared to have been botched by the government and then stolen.
During the subsequent raids, many protesters were killed, though fewer than in recent months, and this period of unrest passed relatively quickly.
Development experts praised Ethiopia's leaders for their visionary infrastructure planning, such as the new commuter train, and for their measurable progress in poverty reduction.
But it appears that this has not prevented the Ethiopian government's internal resentment from intensifying.
And it is taking on a dangerous ethnic form.
Last month, protesters attacked Tigray-run shops in Gondar, an Amharic city, and hatred of the Tigray is becoming more common on social media.
Analysts say the protests put the U.S. and other Western allies in a peculiar position.
The American government used Ethiopia as a base for drone flights over neighboring Somalia, although it recently announced that it had closed that base.
While the West clearly wants to support democracy, it does not want its ally to collapse in an already volatile region.
This, Mr. Abdi said, "is a very fine line."

Greenland shark: The oldest vertebrate is almost 400 years old
Rare sight.
Greenland sharks usually only come to the surface in winter.
This shark was allowed back into the sea after an investigation on board the research vessel Sanna.
He was born in 1624 and swims with a good 1 km / h through the North Atlantic - until today.
Greenland sharks don't give birth until they are 150 years old.
The Greenland shark swims leisurely along the bottom of the North Atlantic, reaching an average of just 1,220 metres in an hour.
Only when it matters does the five-metre-long animal accelerate to a whopping 2.6 km / h - and at this top speed is half as fast as a seal.
However, this slow lifestyle seems to be a panacea for old age.
Julius Nielsen of the University of Copenhagen and his colleagues report in the journal Science that a Greenland shark could be 392 years old.
Madness, says Alexander Scheuerlein from the Max Planck Institute for Demographic Research in Rostock, commenting on this lifespan, which is a world record for vertebrates.
The evolutionary biologist has long suspected that Greenland sharks are becoming stone-old.
Except there was no evidence.
Greenland sharks are difficult to observe, as they live mainly in the Arctic Ocean off the sparsely populated coasts of Canada, Greenland, Norway and Svalbard.
Because they prefer water temperatures of around six degrees Celsius, they usually only appear on the surface in winter.
Accordingly, researchers know little about the lifestyle of Greenland sharks.
They measured their slow-motion speed when they equipped six animals with a transmitter off Svalbard.
These sharks still prey: Researchers found the remains of a seal in one animal's stomach, and another had swallowed the jaw bone of a young polar bear.
They may hunt dormant animals or patrol the bottom of the Arctic Ocean looking for carcasses that stagger down from higher layers of water.
Julius Nielsen and his colleagues studied 28 Greenland sharks caught by fishermen from the depths of the North Atlantic Ocean off Greenland or Spitsbergen between 2010 and 2013.
The smallest shark was just 81 centimetres long, while the largest measured 502 centimetres.
To determine the age of the sharks, they used the carbon-14 method to analyze the lens core of the sharks.
This centre of the eye lens is formed even before the sharks are born, the proteins contained in it are not renewed later.
The two smallest sharks had a remarkable amount of carbon-14 in their lens core.
They were therefore born after the early 1960 "s, when nuclear weapons tests released large quantities of this radioactive carbon into the atmosphere.

In contrast, the third smallest animal at 220 centimetres in length, the lens core contained a small surplus of carbon-14 from nuclear weapons tests, so it may have celebrated its 50th birthday when it was examined in 2012.
All larger Greenland sharks, on the other hand, had normal amounts of carbon-14 in their lens core, which is produced by cosmic rays in the atmosphere.
In fact, the carbon 14 clock showed an age of 335 years for a 493-centimetre Greenland shark, while the record shark, at 502 centimetres, is likely to be 392 years old.
It was known that female Greenland sharks only produce offspring when they are longer than four metres.
The researchers were now able to assign an age to the length.

Since one of the animals with 392 centimetres was probably on the threshold of sexual maturity and its age was determined with 156 years, Greenland sharks obviously take at least one and a half centuries to reproduce.
That, too, should be a world record for vertebrates at the moment.
It is no coincidence that such methusalemes live mainly in icy waters.
The previous record holder, a 211-year-old Greenland whale with a 120-year-old harpoon tip stuck in its neck, was also caught off Alaska.
Due to the low temperatures, the organism of the animals living there often runs on a flame.
So they mature later - and age more slowly.
In order to keep warm in cold water, the animals often grow particularly large.
This is because the volume grows much faster than its surface, which causes the animal to lose heat.
The heat loss of one gram of mouse is therefore much greater than that of one gram of elephant.
Another advantage: you have fewer enemies.
A smaller animal therefore lives more dangerously and should concentrate on having as many offspring as possible as early as possible, explains evolutionary biologist Scheuerlein.
A very large animal, on the other hand, should invest its resources in a long life.

In order to bridge the time until the next pilgrimage to Rome of all altar servers in probably two years, the Oberministrantenrunde St. Anna decided to prepare and carry out a pilgrimage lasting several days.

Various pilgrimage destinations were examined and the decision was finally made for the episcopal city of Freiburg, where a special pilgrimage destination was offered this year on the occasion of the Holy Year of Mercy, with the Door of Mercy at the Freiburg Minster opened for this purpose.
16 Minis from Bittelbronn, Gruol, Haigerloch and Heiligenzimmern set off.
The evening before, Father Storost sent out the pilgrims in a small celebration in St. Anna, blessed the pilgrim crosses and gave the pilgrim blessing.
From Horb we took the train to the starting point of Villingen, where there is also a cathedral of Our Lady and so the pilgrimage route from the cathedral was started.
The individual day tours were framed in the morning and in the evening by a short impulse with different prayers, songs and scriptural texts.
But also on the way the Minis stopped again and again at field crosses, chapels or churches to sing together a song from a specially compiled pilgrim song book.
Parishes of the local parishes were available for overnight stays.
At the stage destinations Alexandra Burkhardt and Heidi Faller provided a tasty as well as fortifying dinner and breakfast.
On the second day we continued via Furtwangen to Gütenbach.
The next day they started the stage to St. Peter, which was the most strenuous part of the way, as they had to first descend about 500 metres in altitude in sweltering heat and then climb again.
The deserved reward was a barbecue at the pond in the evening.
After the morning impulse on the fourth day of pilgrimage in the imposing monastery church of St. Peter, we set off on the final stage to Freiburg.
Visibly relieved and happy, the Minis arrived at Freiburg Cathedral in the late afternoon and passed through the Door of Mercy.
With a small impulse God was thanked here.
In the evening Mass in the cathedral, the Minis arriving at the pilgrimage destination were welcomed by co-ordinator Markus Obert.
After the service, the pilgrims could visit the sacristy and the high altar.
The next day there was still time for the Breisgau metropolis.
In the afternoon we went back to Horb by train.
In the end, all participants agreed that the days were marked by spirituality and a strong community experience.

Nokia 9000 Communicator: The first smartphone
Email and the Internet in slow motion: 20 years ago, Nokia Communicator was launched.
Its successors now dominate the world - its manufacturer suffered a disaster.
The device weighed almost half a kilogram and was more than four times the weight of an iPhone 5.
It was thicker and bigger, so it didn't sit well in the hand.
On the contrary, it was rather clunky.
The built-in memory was initially eight megabytes, which would be enough for about two high-resolution selfies today.
An iPhone now ships with at least 16 gigabytes.
The "Nokia 9000 Communicator" was launched exactly 20 years ago, on August 15, 1996 - and it was the first smartphone.
For a few euros, enthusiasts can still buy the devices on the Internet, but they somehow date back to the Stone Age of the Internet age.
But 20 years ago, the Communicator was a sensation.
The Finnish mobile phone manufacturer had announced the product a few months earlier at the Cebit computer fair in Hanover as a "pocket-sized office."
In fact, the new mobile phone could do a lot for the standards of the time: SMS and e-mails could be sent and received, and the communicator could also be reached by fax.
Even access to websites was possible via an HTML browser, albeit painfully slow.
A calculator was available, a digital address book and an electronic calendar.
There was a small antenna, and the mobile phone could be opened like a laptop.
Then there was a small keyboard and a black-and-white screen.
Pretty proud was the price: 2700 D-Mark, i.e. about 1400 Euro.
The average selling price of a smartphone in Germany was 392 euros in 2015.
No one could have guessed in August 1996 that the Communicator would be the beginning of the smartphone era.
Everything has changed since then.
The smart phones are a success story, though not for Nokia.
The mobile phone division of the Finns experienced an unprecedented disaster, was eventually sold to Microsoft and wound up.
The market is now dominated by suppliers, all of whom came much later than Nokia.
Being online anytime and anywhere is a daily occurrence for many people today.
In 2015, there were nearly two billion smartphone users worldwide.
About 1.4 billion devices have been sold, with Samsung and Apple alone accounting for 555 million units.
Worldwide sales of the devices amount to around 400 billion euros.
Add to that the well-running business of countless app providers and telecommunications companies.
In the meantime, an entire industry has emerged around the smartphone.
The decisive breakthrough to the mass market came at the beginning of 2007, when Apple CEO Steve Jobs announced the introduction of the iPhone at the Mac World.
He promised three devices in one: a music player, a telephone and an Internet communicator, all easy to use via touch screen.
Apple's triumphant march began, and the iPhone is still the company's most important product today.
Nokia, Motorola and Blackberry, which dominated the market, lost out.
They eventually disappeared, and Blackberry has struggled.
Apple and Asian suppliers such as Samsung now call the shots.
Twenty years after its invention, the smartphone is a given.
On average, every German now looks at his mobile phone 88 times a day.
We all have to learn to put our smartphones away, said Janina Kugel, who is responsible for human resources at Siemens.
Permanent accessibility has become both a curse and a blessing.

Adblock Plus, Facebook in "cat-and-mouse game" over ad blocking

NASA climate model: Venus was once habitable
Venus was probably once habitable, according to projections from a new NASA climate model.
Scientists at NASA's Goddard Institute for Space Studies developed a model to discover Venus' past using tools and algorithms similar to those used by climate scientists.
The model was designed to determine whether Venus, with its hot, waterless surface and CO2-dense atmosphere, might have once had Earth-like conditions.
Scientists have previously suggested that Venus' slow rotation could be explained by its dense atmosphere.
But the latest simulation suggests that Venus may have had a thin, Earth-like atmosphere and was still spinning slowly.
The model also illuminated the topography of early Venus.
The planet probably had more arid areas than Earth, but once had enough water and geographical variability to host life and protect it from rapid evaporation.
Early Venus also benefited from a sun that was 30 percent dull.
In the GISS model simulation, the slow rotation of Venus exposes its day side to the sun for nearly two months, GISS scientist Anthony Del Genio said in a press release.
This warms the surface and produces rain that creates a thick layer of clouds, which acts as an umbrella to shield the surface from much of the sun's heat.
The result is average temperatures that are several degrees cooler than those of the Earth today.
The model produced a history of Venus that resembles the evolution previously suspected by planetary scientists.
Although it was once thought to be habitable, Venus was exposed to too much heat and ultraviolet light over billions of years.
Their oceans evaporated and their water vapour was burned away by ultraviolet light.
When its hydrogen escaped, all that was left was a thick atmosphere of carbon dioxide with a deadly greenhouse effect -- Venus as we know it today.
The researchers shared the results of their new Venus climate model in the Geophysical Research Letters.

The latest mission with the Kepler Space Telescope has helped astronomers gather the most complete catalog of rotation rates among the stars in the Pleiades cluster.
The new data will help astronomers understand why stars in the cluster rotate at different rates and how the rotation periods are related to planet formation.

By comparing our results with other star clusters, we hope to learn more about the relationship between a star's mass, its age, and even the history of its solar system, Luisa Rebull, a researcher at Caltech's Infrared Processing and Analysis Center in Pasadena, said in a press release.
The star cluster of the Pleiades is located 445 light years from Earth.
Many stars in this cluster, which formed around 125 million years ago, are now reaching adulthood.
They are spinning the fastest now.
At peak rotation rates, these maturing stars emit large amounts of stellar winds.
As these winds travel through the magnetic fields of the stars, they have a braking effect on the stars.
As a star ages, its rotation rate begins to slow.
Kepler measures the rotation rate of each star by detecting the time between the appearance of a recognizable starspot -- such as sunspots.
The latest catalog of rotation rates indicates that more massive stars spin more slowly than less massive stars.
Rebull compares the stars to dancers, with larger stars pirouetting more slowly than smaller ones.
In the ballet "of the Pleiades, we see that slow rotors tend to be more massive, whereas faster rotors tend to be very bright stars," Rebull said.
Because the star cluster of the Pleiades is so close, it serves as an ideal cosmic laboratory to compare stellar qualities such as rotation rates.
The Pleiades cluster provides an anchor for theoretical models of stellar rotation in both directions, younger and older, Rebull said.
There is still a long way to go and we would like to know more about how, when and why stars slow down their rotation rates and hang up their "dancing shoes."
Rebull and her colleagues have detailed their latest analysis of the rotation rates of the Pleiades in three newspaper reports, which will soon appear in the Astronomical Journal.

Data theft: How perfidious hackers extort their ransom
Programmers of extortion malware are currently targeting companies - and are successful in doing so.

According to a recent survey by malware defense specialists Malwarebytes among 540 companies in North America, Great Britain and Germany, 40 percent of the companies surveyed have been victims of an attack with extortion software at least once, sometimes several times, in the past twelve months.
In Germany, almost 20 percent of companies have already been the target of ransomware extortion.
40 percent of the victims willingly paid the ransoms demanded by the perpetrators in order to be able to use the attacked systems and data again.
According to the observations of Malwarebytes, the perpetrators increasingly specialize their extortion software in attacks on corporate networks.
If they are successful there, the potential ransom to be extorted is significantly higher than for private users.
We are currently witnessing an alarmingly rapid evolution of malware, explains Malwarebytes CEO Marcin Kleczynski in an interview with Die Welt.
In 2008, most malware programs were still designed to send advertisements.
Then the perpetrators discovered extortion software for themselves.
At first, private users were the target, but the shift to corporate attacks has occurred alarmingly quickly in recent months.

Ransomware works according to a simple pattern: Once active on a victim's computer, it searches specifically for recently modified files such as Word, Excel or database files, as well as archives of images and videos.
These files encrypted the Ransomware and deletes the originals permanently.
The software then presents the extortioners "demands.
In order to get the final encryption code to the files, victims must transfer money - usually in the form of the cryptocurrency Bitcoin.
But where the personal photo database is at stake for private users, companies are concerned with sensitive customer data or project databases, without which production stops.
Accordingly, the damage is higher if a Ransomware strikes.
22 percent of the affected German companies reported loss of sales due to ransomware, 13 percent even had to interrupt business completely, in one case people were in danger of their lives.
In Germany, several hospitals have already been the victims of attacks whose patients may be acutely threatened by the loss of medical records.
We always say to victims: don't pay, you're just promoting the problem, Kleczynski says.
But 80 to 90 percent of the companies that pay get their data back.
It is difficult for managers to reject the perpetrators "demands in the face of stagnation in operations.
The hackers, on the other hand, know this and try everything to build a good reputation.

In a recent study, the security researchers at F-Secure examined the user interfaces and contact with the extortioners and came to the conclusion that the perpetrators are actually trying to set up a kind of customer service in order to earn more money.
They explain to their victims via chat how to pay by Bitcoin, set up freely accessible support websites or decrypt sample files for free.
And if private individuals are redeemed after payments of a few hundred euros, companies sometimes have to negotiate hard and pay five-figure sums in order to get their data back unencrypted.

Given the potentially high and relatively risk-free profits from ransomware extortion, the hackers are becoming more professional and share the work, explains security expert Chester Wisniewski from the antivirus provider Sophos: "A single person can write a ransomware approximately within a week."
It is more likely, however, that it is three or four people.
The programmers then sell their malicious software in the form of a software kit to the actual blackmailers.
The previous malware kits were created by purchasing the malware itself, advice and additional tools for a one-time, fixed price of between $1000 and $10,000.
It comes with a customization tool so that smaller configurations, appearance and branding can be changed, Wisniewski says.
The extortionists then look for more hackers to spread the newly purchased software among the victims.
We live in a service economy.
So you log into one of the underground forums, buy the set from a criminal and commission another to install the software on as many PCs as possible.
Payment is made per infected computer.
Usually the criminals then hire spammers to spread it, Wisniewski explains.
The risk of Ransomware is now known at many companies, which back up their data better.
More than 50 percent of the company IT managers in the Malwarebytes survey trust that they can fend off ransomware using file back-ups and scanner software.
Accordingly, the perpetrators are already pursuing new strategies.

If the encryption of data alone is no longer a sufficient threat for successful extortion, the perpetrators instead threaten to publish sensitive data such as customer lists or price calculations, explains Malwarebytes CEO Marcin Kleczynski.
Depending on the type of data, the damage potential is thus many times higher than before.
The perpetrators could also target completely new targets on the Internet of Things in the future.
At the Defcon hacker conference, security researchers demonstrated how they could get a thermostat connected to the Internet under their control.
In the middle of winter, unlocking such a blocked heater could well be worth a ransom to some victims.
If the perpetrators then block an entire production line in a factory instead of heating in the future, ransomware could also become an issue in Industry 4.0.

Relaxing night: Tips against insomnia
In the evening you roll around forever, at night you lie awake for hours, in the morning you can no longer think about sleep long before the alarm rings.
This is far from relaxing.

After all, one is in good company with such problems: According to the Robert Koch Institute, about a quarter of adults have sleep disorders, and more than ten percent often or permanently experience their sleep as not restorative.
How do sleep problems or sleep disorders manifest themselves?
There are several forms of sleep disorders, and they can be based on a variety of causes, emphasizes Hans-Günter Weeß, board member of the German Society for Sleep Research and Sleep Medicine.
What is commonly understood by this, however, is insomnia, i.e. a disturbance of falling asleep and sleeping through.

Straight through sleep feels many humans as unsatisfactory or insufficient, says Jens Wagenknecht, executive committee member in the German family doctor federation with practice in the Lower Saxony Varel.
What's behind sleep disorders?
The causes of sleep disorders are complex.
This can be due to organic, psychological or behavioural factors, as well as medication.
It is not uncommon for a sleep disorder to be an expression of another disease.
Very early waking is common, especially with depression, Weeß says.
And it may be that different factors determine each other.
For example, someone who has a herniated disc can lie down badly, wakes up every two to three hours and possibly begins to think about everyday problems and worries, Weeß gives an example.
This leads to tension, and sleep is no longer possible.
When should I go to the doctor with insomnia?
Anyone who does not sleep well for at least three nights a week for a period of one month and is impaired during the day should see a doctor, advises Weeß.

The impairment can look very different: one is exhausted, tired, unrested, has difficulty with attention and concentration, is easily irritable, has mood swings or physical complaints such as stomach or headaches.
In order to alleviate the sleep disorder, it is important to find out its causes.
Treatment options include behavioural changes, cognitive behavioural therapy or medication - classic sleeping pills only in exceptional cases and for a maximum of two weeks.
There are hardly any established sleep physicians in Germany, emphasizes Prof. Ingo Fietze, head of the interdisciplinary sleep medicine center of the Charité University Medical Center Berlin.
Therefore one should first turn to the family doctor in case of sleep problems, advises Weeß.
He can clarify with examinations whether the problems have a physical cause.
Who should go to the sleep lab, and what happens there?

For example, physicians advise examinations in the sleep laboratory in cases of snoring with respiratory failure, pathological daytime fatigue, sleepwalkers, or if the cause of a sleep disturbance is not found, Fietze explains.
You don't really have to prepare for the examination.
You should spend the day as normal.
Just don't take a nap, please, Fietze says.
After wiring, you go to bed at your normal time.
In addition to the electrodes on the body, you wear nose glasses, a chest strap and a sensor on your finger.
In addition, a camera on the ceiling records the sleeping person.
How can those affected get a grip on the problems?
There are quite a few adjustments you can make for a better sleep.

Weeß enumerates: Regular bedtime and getting up, not lying in bed too long, not sleeping during the day, not watching TV to fall asleep, avoiding alcohol and not looking at the clock at night - then you start to calculate immediately, and that is not at all conducive.

Thuringia: Zeiss Meditec closer to the billion turnover
High demand for medical technology in Asia has boosted Carl Zeiss Meditec's sales.
In the first nine months of the financial year that began in October, consolidated sales rose by 6.7 percent to 798.6 million euros, as the listed company announced on Friday in Jena.
The Asian business grew disproportionately by 17.1 percent.
Earnings before interest and taxes rose from 89.5 million euros to 110.5 million euros, according to the interim balance sheet.
The Jena-based medical technology group intends to exceed the turnover mark of one billion euros this financial year, the Executive Board confirmed.
Zeiss Meditec manufactures devices and equipment for medical practices and clinics.
The company, which belongs to the optics and electronics group Carl Zeiss (Oberkochen), employs almost 3000 people.
